reasoning:
The critique targets a central step in Sec. 3.2: that (unbounded) linear/separable views plus fat-tailed value-efficiency imply a very narrow target requiring near-exact resource configuration. If that step failed, the essay’s case that “most plausible views are fussy” would be meaningfully weakened, though not entirely (the essay also argues for fussiness via multiplicative fragility in Sec. 2 and via bounded-view analyses), hence moderate centrality.

However, the critique’s refutation is limited. It mainly argues the authors didn’t provide an implementation-level model of resources, separable parcels, and the ‘single’ optimal arrangement, and that degeneracy/symmetries could yield broad near-optimal basins. This is a fair demand for additional justification and points to a potential gap, but it doesn’t directly show the essay’s claim is false: separability at some granularity is part of what “linear” is doing in their argument, and even with many near-optima, a fat-tailed distribution could still make “mostly-great” rare. Also, the critique somewhat conflates two different parts of the essay: (i) linearity/separability across resource parcels, and (ii) institutional entanglement examples from Sec. 2; the authors need not claim institutions are parcelable for the linear-resource argument to go through.

Correctness is fairly high: it is true that the essay doesn’t fully specify the action space/ontology and that multiple near-optimal policies might exist; and it’s right that ‘single arrangement’ talk is an additional assumption (or at least under-argued). But some claims are overstated (e.g., that without a formal model the narrow-target conclusion is “unearned”; the essay gives informal reasons via separability + fat tails, so it’s not pure handwaving).

Clarity is good and focused, with little dead weight. Overall, it raises a legitimate but patchable under-specification/robustness worry, creating some pressure on one pillar of the “fussy linear views” case, but it doesn’t strongly undercut the broader conclusion.
title: Linear optimization often permits multiple near-optimal solutions through degeneracy and symmetry
